Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES: Students' Pathways into Computer and Information Sciences Majors:A Study of Community College Men and Women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Women's enrollment in computer and information sciences (CIS) majors and completion of CIS undergraduate and graduate degrees has declined in the US over the last 20 years. Efforts to reverse this trend have been limited by a lack of research on the pathways into and out of CIS majors, including community college pathways. Community colleges are of interest because they attract a higher proportion of females and a broader demographic in terms of age and socioeconomic status than 4-year universities. This study is designed to collect data that can be used to inform efforts to encourage women to pursue CIS majors by exploring the experiences of women and men in community colleges taking introductory programming courses and the impact of those experiences on their decisions to pursue a four-year CIS degree. The study is based on theoretical frameworks that suggest the importance of motivation, parent and peer support, and previous computer use, especially computer game play. The researchers will recruit 700 female and male students in introductory programming courses at community colleges that are key feeder schools to the University of California (4-year public universities) CIS departments. Participants will complete three surveys over two years, and a subsample will be interviewed.

Broader Impacts: The findings of the study will provide much-needed data on three widely held assumptions about gender differences in pathways to CIS majors; recent reviews suggest that there is little actual research on the role of motivation, family support and computer use (particularly digital gaming) among community college CIS students. That which exists was collected before the availability of widely accessible mobile (e.g., cell phone) and multiplayer Internet games, is short on theory, does not examine variation within gender, and lacks a design or analytic approach that allows for causal inference or the determination of effect sizes. This study will overcome these limitations and provide data on why students choose introductory programming courses and how those influential factors relate to decisions to pursue CIS at a 4-year institution. In addition, this study will contribute to knowledge about the role of digital gaming in choice of CIS major, since prior research focuses on frequency of game play rather than on type of play.

This research will inform efforts to increase the number of students who pursue CIS majors at 4-year universities. Enrollment in these majors has dropped in the last five years, especially for women. But efforts to close the gender gap have been limited by a lack of rigorous research on students? pathways into and through community college; little is known about why CIS students transfer to 4-year institutions. This research aims to fill this gap by identifying the characteristics and prior experience of students who take introductory programming courses, and whether those characteristics and current experience in CIS courses predict intention to go on to pursue a CIS major at a 4-year university.

ProgramElement.Text: RES ON GENDER IN SCI & ENGINE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results of this study have broad implications for increasing diversity in STEM fields by focusing on an understudied population. There are over 13 million students enrolled in community colleges (CC) nationwide; they represent greater racial/ethnic diversity and are more likely to be from lower socioeconomic groups than students in 4-year colleges and universities. However, research on the development of interest and the pursuit of computer and information sciences (CIS) education in this population lags far behind research on students in 4-year institutions.

There are several unique contributions of this study to social science and computer science education research and practice. First, the data were collected from over 700 men and women taking a computer science class at one of 15 community colleges across the state of California, allowing us to test existing beliefs about gender differences and to explore the experiences of women and men from underrepresented minority groups. Second, we have collected data on multiple levels of influence--the individual, relational, and institutional—which allow us to tease out the relative importance of these factors. Third, we have collected longitudinal data that we used to measure initial intentions, as well as how experiences in an Introductory Programming class and changes in motivation influence student intentions to study CIS. The findings are important for two reasons: 1) they offer evidence that can be used to create or strengthen strategies to increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities that pursue CIS, particularly at 4-year institutions, and 2) they challenge some widely held beliefs about how to increase diversity in CIS.

Intellectual Merit. The results of this study provide much-needed data on three widely held assumptions about gender differences in pathways to CIS majors that were based on studies of 4-year university students who are, on average, younger, less likely to be working or have children, and more likely to be pursuing a degree than seeking professional development. Overall, the results confirm prior studies that show motivation plays an important role in students’ intentions to pursue CIS, however expectations for success were more important for female students, and the value placed on computing was more important for male students. The results partially support the assumption that preparation is an important factor in students’ intentions to pursue CIS: programming experience played a role for men only, and taking a higher level mathematics course played a role for women only. The study also supports prior research that shows how digital gaming and peer encouragement
have a positive influence on students’ choice of a computing major. The findings also challenge some widely held beliefs about why so few women pursue CIS. Unlike prior studies of 4-year college students, women’s intentions to pursue CIS were not related to family support, having a parent that works in CS, having a mentor, prior programming experience, or gender stereotypes.

Broader Impact. The results provide information about students’ pathways into and through community college that can be used to inform efforts to increase the number of students who earn CIS degrees and pursue CIS at 4-year universities. The findings highlight the importance of preparation and interactions with professors for male students, and of motivational, relational, and behavioral factors for women, specifically peer support, expectations for success, and computer gaming. Based on these findings, we have made several recommendations for community colleges that may increase women’s and underrepresented minorities' interest in pursuing CIS, including how to make gaming competitions more widely appealing, and have dissemi...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The results of this study have broad implications for increasing diversity in STEM fields by focusing on an understudied population. There are over 13 million students enrolled in community colleges (CC) nationwide; they represent greater racial/ethnic diversity and are more likely to be from lower socioeconomic groups than students in 4-year colleges and universities. However, research on the development of interest and the pursuit of computer and information sciences (CIS) education in this population lags far behind research on students in 4-year institutions. There are several unique contributions of this study to social science and computer science education research and practice. First, the data were collected from over 700 men and women taking a computer science class at one of 15 community colleges across the state of California, allowing us to test existing beliefs about gender differences and to explore the experiences of women and men from underrepresented minority groups. Second, we have collected data on multiple levels of influence--the individual, relational, and institutional—which allow us to tease out the relative importance of these factors. Third, we have collected longitudinal data that we used to measure initial intentions, as well as how experiences in an Introductory Programming class and changes in motivation influence student intentions to study CIS. The findings are important for two reasons: 1) they offer evidence that can be used to create or strengthen strategies to increase the number of women and underrepresented minorities that pursue CIS, particularly at 4-year institutions, and 2) they challenge some widely held beliefs about how to increase diversity in CIS. Intellectual Merit. The results of this study provide much-needed data on three widely held assumptions about gender differences in pathways to CIS majors that were based on studies of 4-year university students who are, on average, younger, less likely to be working or have children, and more likely to be pursuing a degree than seeking professional development. Overall, the results confirm prior studies that show motivation plays an important role in studentsÆ intentions to pursue CIS, however expectations for success were more important for female students, and the value placed on computing was more important for male students. The results partially support the assumption that preparation is an important factor in studentsÆ intentions to pursue CIS: programming experience played a role for men only, and taking a higher level mathematics course played a role for women only. The study also supports prior research that shows how digital gaming and peer encouragement have a positive influence on studentsÆ choice of a computing major. The findings also challenge some widely held beliefs about why so few women pursue CIS. Unlike prior studies of 4-year college students, womenÆs intentions to pursue CIS were not related to family support, having a parent that works in CS, having a mentor, prior programming experience, or gender stereotypes. Broader Impact. The results provide information about studentsÆ pathways into and through community college that can be used to inform efforts to increase the number of students who earn CIS degrees and pursue CIS at 4-year universities. The findings highlight the importance of preparation and interactions with professors for male students, and of motivational, relational, and behavioral factors for women, specifically peer support, expectations for success, and computer gaming. Based on these findings, we have made several recommendations for community colleges that may increase womenÆs and underrepresented minorities' interest in pursuing CIS, including how to make gaming competitions more widely appealing, and have disseminated the results of our research to national audiences that include educators, administrators, researchers, and program developers.
